4. Combining FT and UePb analysis applied to detrital zircon

The pioneering work that combined both FT and UePb analysis
in detrital zircons was made by Carter and Moss (1999). While each
detrital zircon dating technique may provide unique source infor-
mation, in any study, there invariably remain questions about each
method’s limitations. For example, UeThePb dates are character-
ized by a high resistance to thermal overprinting and may therefore
not represent an immediate terrane, instead deriving from more
geographically and temporally distal sources due to polycyclic
history. Similarly, it remains unclear whether a measured FTM age
relates to source cooling and/or zircon formation. Detrital zircon
data derived from either the FTM or UeThePb methods are thus
inherently ambiguous, and their separate use may result in a biased
or misleading provenance interpretation. By adopting a dual zircon
dating approach, combining both FT and UeThePb analyses on the
same samples and/or grains, such limitations can be overcome, and
the optimum amount of provenance information that relates to the
age structure and thermal evolution of the immediate source
terranes can be extracted (Carter and Bristow, 2000).

This work improved the methodology described in Carter
and Moss (1999). The ages found in both methods (detailed in
the Tables 2 and 3) were obtained in the same grains and, more
specifically, in the same areas of the grains. Initially, each sample
was mapped by optical microscopy and dated. Then the grains were
dated by the FTM and the UeThePb method. The etching applied in
the FTM helped to indicate at which specific area of grain the
spot laser should be applied. This area presented uniform FT
distribution.

5. Results

5.1. Fission track methodology

In Table 2 are the fission track data ages and Fig. 3 shows the FT
age distribution of 96 grains distributed in nine samples from the
Vale do Rio do Peixe formation. In Fig. 3, we present all FT zircon
data in a frequency versus age (Ma) histogram, showing two main
peaks at 525 ?15 Ma and 354 ? 6 Ma. The present diagram shows
an asymptotic curve, suggesting three or more populations of age
groups.

To distinguish among different age populations, we plotted the
nine samples in a normalized age versus FT zircon age (Ma)
Fig. 3. FT ages distribution for all dated zircon grains of Vale do Rio do Peixe Forma-
tion. The solid line represents the relative probability.
probability diagram (Fig. 4). The process recognized three main
histogram groups: (i) red lines represent populations in the
primary age range (from ca. 300 to 239 Ma), (ii) green lines
represent those from 500 to 650 Ma, and (iii) blue lines represent
multiple populations, such as sample ZGC7 with two age pop-
ulations from 490e460 Ma to 720e860 Ma.

The first group of samples (red lines in Fig. 4) had zircon ages
from ca. 239 to 339, 353 to 369 and 581 to 637 Ma (ZSE12), from
277 to 303 Ma, 422 to 448 Ma and 510 to 598 Ma (ZNP9), from 239
to 334 Ma, 439 to 440 Ma and 550 to 616 Ma (ZAL13) and from 250
to 332 Ma, 359 to 462 Ma and 554 to 614 Ma (ZEM11). These
samples present dominant ages from 239 Ma to 339 Ma and two
subordinate older zircon age populations.

The second group of samples (blue lines in Fig. 4) has
a normalized age probability histogram ranging from 345e501 to
739e825 Ma (Sample ZGC7) and from 244 to 327, 422 to 451 and
591 to 648 Ma. The third group of samples (green lines in Fig. 4) is
dominated by zircon ages from 497 to 696 Ma (samples ZPV22,
ZFM8 and ZPI23) but also includes ages from 280 to 461 Ma
(samples ZFM8 and ZPI23).

5.2. UePb in situ zircon data

Because the Th/U ratios vary from 0.20 to 1.57, the zircon grain
UePb ages obtained are magmatic. A Th/U ratio greater than 0.2
indicates igneous zircons as opposed to metamorphic zircons,
which usually have very low values (10?2 to 10?3) (Cates and
Mojzsis, 2009). In Fig. 5A, the distribution of all dated zircons
distinguishes major age populations with main peaks at
513 ? 23 Ma, 1007 ? 15 Ma, 1776 ? 24 Ma, and 2024 ? 30 Ma and
one zircon at 2658?66 Ma. The same figure shows the distribution
of FT zircon ages for comparison.

For individual samples, the three analyzed samples represent
very important Brazilian zircons formed from 514 to 668 Ma
(sample ZPI23), 512 to 679 Ma (ZEM11) and 512 to 624 Ma (ZGC7),
respectively. The second important population of zircon ages
comprise the Paleoproterozoic zircons, which were formed from
1758 to 2066 Ma (ZPI23), 1681 to 2085 Ma (ZEM11) and 1630 to
1879 Ma (ZGC7). Both populations can be recognized as Fields I and
III in Fig. 6, and a subordinate population is represented by the
zircon aged from w1.0 to 1.2 Ga, as Field II in Fig. 6. We also
recognized one Archean and three early Neoproterozoic zircon
local occurrences.

5.3. Discussion of results

FT zircon data are usually younger than those ages obtained by
the LA-MC-ICP-MS (Fig. 5), range from 239 to 825 Ma, and can be
related to the four main orogenic cycles of the South American
plate: the Gondwanide (GW, 230e300 Ma), Famatinian and Cuya-
nia (FC, 460e490 Ma), Brazilian (BR, 500e650 Ma) and early Bra-
zilian (eBR, 696e825 Ma).

The Neoproterozoic orogenic cycles are well distributed and
documented in the South America. Accretion of Famatinian Terrane
and Cuyana Terrane in Central Andes occurred at 460 Ma Famati-
nian cycle in northern Chile and the Argentine Puna formed mainly
from 490 to 470 Ma early to middle Ordovician arcs. In the Late
Paleozoic (300e230 Ma) took place a very important orogenic
event at the margin of the pan-Pacific Gondwana, that is described
as Gondwanides Orogeny. These are very well documented at the
western South America margin in the Andean Mountains (e.g.,
Ramos, 2009; Ramos and Alemán, 2000), and responsible by the
Fig. 5. (A) FT and UePb zircon ages distribution of sedimentary samples from the Vale do Rio
The circle represents the laser spot area obtained during the laser ablation UePb method.
input of the zircons aged from w300 Ma to 250 Ma in the sedi-
mentary cycle of the South American Platform.

These cycles appear in Fig. 4 as red, blue, green and pink,
respectively. This information suggests provenance of at least four
different sources in terms of age grouping in the Bauru Basin.
However, most zircons are recycled because the main source area
for the sediments was likely the Paleozoic Paraná Basin. We spec-
ulate that these zircons reached 220 ?C during the main exhuma-
tion processes of the South American Plate, especially during
orogenic processes that affected the plate as well. Fig. 5 presents
ages obtained by both methods. Even when in the same grain, most
zircon ages derived via FTM analysis are younger than those
derived using the UeThePb method. This suggests that zircon
crystallization occurs at approximately 850 ?C, the temperature
associated with UeThePb dating, while the zircon tracks form at
approximately 220 ?C.

To understand the obtained ages with combined zircon methods,
we plotted the three samples against both UePb and FTM zircon
ages. The integration of both sets of data allows us to distinguish
different source areas for the 90- to 100-Ma-old sediments of the
Vale do Rio do Peixe Formation, which is composed of Brazilian,
Early Neoproterozoic, Mesoproterozoic and Paleoproterozoic source
rocks (in declining order of age) (Figs. 5A and 6). The analyzed
zircons show a clear provenance of Brazilian aged zircons, ranging
from 445 ? 14 to 708 ? 18 Ma. The second important group is the
Paleoproterozoic zircons formed from 1879 ? 23 to 2085 ? 27 Ma.
Minor occurrences of Early Neoproterozoic and Mesoproterozoic
zircons formed from 836 ? 15 to 1780 ? 38 Ma provide additional
information on sedimentary input in the Bauru Basin. These zircons
are incorporated from the source areas of Brazilian Belts, such as
those situated west of Bauru Basin in the Tocatins Province and
PaleoproterozoicRhyacianTerranes located in the northern, western
or eastern Bauru Basin. The Mesoproterozoic zircons are sourced
from areas situated to the west (e.g., the maficeultramafic
complexes of the Goiás Massif, as discussed by Ferreira Filho et al.,
2010) or to the north (from the Mesoproterozoic basin of the
Espinhaço region). A detailed comparison of FTM apparent ages and
UePb crystallization ages for samples ZCG7, ZEM11 and ZPI23
provide the following conclusions. First, the three analyzed samples
contain grains with Neoproterozoic ages (500e700 Ma) and Early
Neo to Mesoproterozoic ages (800e996 Ma) that were exhumed at
do Peixe Formation. (B) Back Scattering images with UePb (upper) and FT (lower) ages.

different times and possibly from differentplaces, suggestingorigins
in a reworked source (e.g., Paleozoic Paraná rocks). Second, ZPI23
contained Paleoproterozoic or Archean zircons that were exhumed
around 600 Ma (A2, B2, C3, C7 and D7), possibly from a basement
inlier within the mobile Brazilian Belt located either in the Goiás
Massif or the São Francisco Craton. Additionally, ZCG7 contains three
grains with Mesoproterozoic ages that were exhumed during Early
Neoproterozoic from 739 to 825 Ma. These zircons may be related to
the maficeultramafic complexes of the Goiás Massif, which were
incorporated by metamorphic and deformational processes during
the Mara Rosa orogeny, a 700e800 Ma orogenic process in the
Brazilian Shield, similar to the Goiás Massif and situated west of
Bauru Basin. Finally, ZEM11 shows a cluster of zircons with Paleo-
proterozoic age (1800e2100 Ma) that were exhumed from late
Devonian to Permian time (C1, J2, F5, C8, F8, A9 and H9) and range
from370to 250 Ma.ZirconsI4, E6, B8, A9 and D10 crystallized during
the late stages of the Brazilian Cycle (586e512 Ma) and were
exhumed from 381 to 250 Ma. Both zircon sets provide important
information about exhumation time in the South American Plate
related to the Gondwanide orogeny.

The Bauru Group zircons analyzed here were reworked sedi-
ments from the Paleozoic to Triassic Paraná Basin and from inlier
basement rocks formed during the Precambrian. Additionally, the
FTM zircon ages may reflect denudation processes extending from
the total to partial annealing zones at different orogenic cycles of
the South American Plate from the Neoproterozoic to the Triassic, in
particular the Early Brazilian, Brazilian and Famatinian/Cuyania
(Ordovician to Silurian) and the Gondwanide (Carboniferous to
Early Triassic) orogenies. Those FT zircon ages close to 250 Ma are
interpreted as belonging to the late Gondwanide orogeny, as
recorded in the Permian sediments of the Paraná Basin.

6. Conclusions

The combination of high-temperature UePb zircon dating and
intermediate- to low-temperature FTM zircon dating provided
a powerful tool for unraveling the origin of the rocks and mor-
photectonic events in the geological evolution of the South Amer-
ican Plate. The UeThePb method provided consistent information
about the main source areas of the Vale do Rio do Peixe Formation
sediments, formed between 90 and 100 Ma and dominated by
Brazilian and Rhyacian zircons with additional Early Neo-
proterozoic and Mesoproterozoic (or Greenvilian coeval material)
sources. The main sedimentary source for this basin originated in
the Paraná Basin sediments containing reworked zircons of the
Paleoproterozoic to Eopaleozoic crystalline basement or in the
western and northern Bauru Basin basement rocks. The early
Neoproterozoic zircons could have been transported from the Goiás
Massif region, a region west of the Bauru Basin containing a Mara
Rosa orogenic belt, which formed at that time. The FTM data can be
grouped in four distinct age groups: the early Neoproterozoic,
Brazilian, OrdovicianeSilurian and CarboniferouseEarly Triassic.
The exhumation processes of the early Neoproterozoic and Brazil-
ian are related to basement inliers situated to the west of the Bauru
Group units (e.g., the Goiás Central Massif). The Paleozoic ages
analyzed here are grouped in the two main mountain formations of
the western South American Platform: the Famatinian and Gond-
wanide orogenies. The latter is well represented by FTM apparent
ages from w370 to 250 Ma and indicates the passage of zircon from
the total to partial annealing zone during the Gondwanide Cycle.
Continued comparative analyses of FTM and UeThePb data are
needed, but the combination of the two techniques is promising.
FTM applications in zircon dating remain coherent with known
geological data.

Manuscript Number:  
 
Title: RECOGNITION OF MAIN TECTONIC EVENTS OF THE SOUTH AMERICAN PLATFORM BY 
DETRITAL ZIRCON FISSION TRACK AND U-Pb DATING OF THE INTRACRATONIC MESOZOIC BAURU 
BASIN, BRAZIL  
 
Article Type: Regular Article 
 
Keywords: Zircon fission-track, U-Pb in situ dating, Bauru Basin, Paraná Basin, South America Tectonic 
Events 
 
Corresponding Author: M.Sc. Airton Natanael Coelho Dias, M.D. 
 
Corresponding Author's Institution: Faculdade de Ciências e Tecnologia/UNESP 
 
First Author: Airton N Dias, PhD. 
 
Order of Authors: Airton N Dias, PhD.; Farid Chemale Jr, PhD.; Carlos A Tello S., PhD.; Peter C 
Hackspacher, PhD.; Cleber J Soares, PhD.; Camilo I Aristizábal, MSc; Sandro Guedes, PhD. 
 
Abstract: Intracratonic basins usually record the polyhistory of cratons or plates during the deposition 
time as well as the remote geological time. Fission-track (FT) combined with U-Pb in situ analyses of 
detrital zircons thus reveals the polyhistory of this type of basin. To distinguish the crustal accretion of 
the South American Platform, 29 sandstone samples of the depositional sequences of the intracratonic 
Bauru Basin, formed between 90 and 73 Ma, were dated. The results of U-Pb zircon dating integrated 
with paleocurrent information and potential source areas suggest that the Rhyacian (Transmazonian 
Cycle, 2.2-1.9 Ga), Statherian (1.8-1.68 Ga), Sunsás-Grenvile (1.2-0.9 Ga), Tonian (Early Brasiliano, 0.9 
to 0.75 Ga) and Brasiliano (0.65 to 0.50 Ga) are the main source areas. The FT data provide important 
evidence of rapid uplift during the Early Brasiliano and Brasiliano and yield two main Paleozoic age 
populations, one between 500 and 360 Ma and other between 345 and 230 Ma. These age populations 
are interpreted to reflect the main tectonic event along the western margin of the South American 
Platform that affected the platform's internal composition by uplift and exhumation. These materials 
have been recycled by sedimentary processes in a continental intraplate environment without 
attaining the necessary temperature to reset the FT isotopic system of the studied zircons and thereby 
depositing during the Upper Cretaceous.

1. Introduction 40 

 41 

Zircon has become one the most important minerals for studying the evolution of 42 

sedimentary basins. U-Pb detrital zircon studies are applied to different types of basins to 43 

reveal their provenance or sedimentary source and to correlate sedimentary sequences, 44 

maximum depositional ages and the tectonic environment. On the other hand, the FT zircon 45 

methodology reveals the low-temperature history of zircon from 200 to 320°C (Garver and 46 

Brandon 1994; Tagami, 1998; Carter and Moss, 1999; Liu et al., 2001; Bernet et al., 2001), 47 

which can provide much information regarding the denudation process in different tectonic 48 

situations and an estimation of the maximum depositional age. The combination of the two 49 

techniques, applied to detrital zircons in sedimentary rocks, can therefore provide very 50 

important information regarding high-temperature and intermediate- to low-temperature 51 

geologic events such as the igneous and metamorphic crystallization of zircons, 52 



morphotectonic events (uplift, denudation, etc.) and sedimentary provenance, as described 53 

above. The best samples for performing FT thermochronology on detrital zircon are from 54 

synorogenic sediments formed during the Cenozoic, such as those in Himalayas and Andes, 55 

where it is a well-established tool for examining the cooling and exhumation history of 56 

convergent mountain belts (Garver et al., 1999; Bernet et al., 2006). In this area of rapid 57 

exhumation rates, low-temperature thermochronological systems, such as FT and U-Th/He 58 

on zircon and apatite and 40Ar/39Ar on mica or feldspar, have recorded the recent history 59 

without the memory of earlier events (Stuart, 2002; Bernet et al., 2006; Carrapal et al., 2009).  60 

Combined FTM and U-Pb detrital zircon analyses are also used in different types of 61 

basins, to better understand the relationship between sedimentary sources and the infilling of 62 

a basin (Carter & Moss, 1999). In some cases, it is possible to determine the deposition, 63 

accretional events and metamorphism of metamorphic complexes along the ancestral margin, 64 

such as that of the ancestral Pacific margin of Gondwana, Chile during the Mesozoic 65 

(Thomson & Hervé, 2002). (U-Th)/He and U/Pb analyses are also integrated and applied to 66 

detrital zircons from the Lower Jurassic Navajo Sandstone, which is made up of erg deposits 67 

and situated close to a convergent margin but in a more stable platform. A large fraction of 68 

zircons formed between 1200 and 950 Ma but cooled below ?180 °C ca. 500–250 Ma, 69 

recording the formation of the Rodinia Supercontinent and later crustal convergence related 70 

to the Appalachian orogenesis situated to the east of the Navarro Basin (Rahl et al., 2003). 71 

Intracratonic basins, which are the focus of this study, are located on the stable 72 

continental lithosphere (Sloss and Speed, 1974), located some distance from stretched or 73 

convergent margins (Allen & Armitage, 2012). These basins are characterized by low-rate 74 

sedimentation over a period of one hundred million years, a thickness of no more than 5 km 75 

and a widely superficial distribution (over one million square kilometers). The sedimentation 76 

may extend back more than 600 Ma, such as for the Central Australian or Espinhaço Basins 77 



(Shaw et al. 1991, Chemale et al., 2012), or less than 400 Ma, as for the Phanerozoic 78 

Michigan and Paraná Basins (Sloss, 1963, Zalan et al., 1990). Their sediments can thus 79 

register a multifarious history of the cratonic areas that can be associated with geological 80 

events of extensional or convergent margins situated at distances as large as one thousand 81 

kilometers. Many important records of these events may be found in the intraplate continental 82 

environment, as described for the Phanerozoic intracratonic basins (Lindsay, 2002).  83 

The main purpose of this study was to understand the geological history of the 84 

intracratonic Bauru Basin, formed during the Mesozoic at the center of the South American 85 

Platform, and to determine its main source areas and maximum depositional age based on 86 

the apparent and absolute ages obtained from the zircon of sedimentary rocks by FTM and U-87 

Pb in situ via LA-MC-ICP-MS analysis, respectively. Furthermore, the combination of both 88 

zircon ages is applied to reveal the main crustal formation and denudation events of the 89 

South American Platform.  90 

 91 

 92 

2. Geological setting 93 

 94 

The study area is located in the middle of the South America Platform (Fig. 1), 95 

where the Paleozoic to Triassic sedimentary sequence of the Paraná Basin, the lava flows 96 

(Paraná Basalts) and associated aeolian sediments (Botucatu Fm.) of the Lower Cretaceous 97 

São Bento Group and the Upper Cretaceous sedimentary sequence of the Bauru Basin are 98 

distributed, all of which formed in an intracratonic environment. The average crustal thickness 99 

is ca. 40 km, and the area is located ca. 500 km away from the eastern Brazilian passive 100 

margin and 1500 km from the Andean Mountains.  101 

 102 



2.1. Bauru Basin 103 

The Bauru Basin occurs as a continental sequence up to 320 m thick (Paula e Silva 104 

et al., 2009) in southeastern and central Brazil, which unconformably overlies the Lower 105 

Cretaceous Serra Geral magmatic units (or Paraná Basalts and related rocks) and sediments 106 

of the São Bento Group (Suguio, 1997). These continental sediments represent the last 107 

important sedimentation in the intraplate (or intracratonic) position of the South America 108 

Platform, widespread over approximately 370,000 km2 in the states of Paraná, São Paulo, 109 

Minas Gerais and Goiás, Brazil (Fernandes and Coimbra, 1996; Paula e Silva et al., 2009). 110 

The age of the Bauru Group is still a subject of debate but is generally accepted to be the 111 

Upper Cretaceous, as evidenced by the vertebrate fossiliferous content and upper alkaline 112 

rocks (Fernandes and Coimbra, 1996, Paula e Silva et al., 2009), and correlated to the 113 

evolution stages of the Santos Basin, at the Brazilian passive margin (Pereira et al., 1986). A 114 

regional unconformity is also marked at the top of Bauru sedimentary units, which is 115 

described as the Sul-Americana (King, 1956) or Japi (Almeida, 1964) surface. The age of this 116 

regional surface is estimated to be between 78 and 73 Ma (Almeida & Carneiro, 1998). 117 

During the deposition of the Bauru Basin, between 90 Ma and 73 Ma, the basin was marked 118 

by arid to semi-arid conditions with alternating hot/dry and rainy seasons. These climatic 119 

conditions enabled a diversification of fauna (invertebrate and vertebrates) and flora in a 120 

depositional environment with an alluvial plain, braided to meandering rivers and small lakes 121 

(Carvalho et al., 2004). 122 

Paula e Silva et al. (2009) described the main stratigraphic units in light of the 123 

sequence stratigraphy and based on field and drill-hole information. They defined three main 124 

depositional phases separated by two erosive/non-depositional phases, as shown in figure 2. 125 

The initial phase of the deposition of the Bauru Basin, Depositional Sequence 1, is marked 126 

by the regional unconformity on the São Bento Group units, which is related to the tectonic 127 



adjustment of the South America Platform due to thermal cooling of the lithosphere after 128 

intense Paraná magmatism (Milani, 1997). The sedimentation was controlled by earlier 129 

lineaments and manifested as aeolian-fluvial sandstones and lacustrine mudstones, which 130 

filled the valley on the basaltic substratum. These units are interdigitated as part of the Caiuá 131 

and Pirapozinho formations (Paula e Silva et al., 2005). They formed in an endorreic fluvial 132 

system, which evolved into meandering rivers that flowed to a shallow lacustrine environment, 133 

with main influx towards the northeast (Paula e Silva et al. 2009).  134 

Depositional Sequence 2 represents a new subsidence process associated with a 135 

fluvial braided system, with dominant sand deposits and subordinate clay-rich sedimentation. 136 

Meandering and aeolian dunes facies occurred locally. These sedimentary deposits compose 137 

the Anastácio Fm (Fig. 2) and were deposited in erosional unconformity on the Caiuá and 138 

Pirapozinho Formation units. 139 

The third tectonic event occurred in the Bauru Basin with the deposition of the 140 

sediments of Depositional Sequence 3. A local fluvial braided and channelized system was 141 

installed over the Depositional Sequence 2 units, the sediment record of the Birigui Fm. (Fig. 142 

2). The main sedimentation of Depositional Sequence 3 was manifested as shallow 143 

lacustrine and a meandering system as part of the Araçatuba and Lower Member of the 144 

Adamantina Formation (Vale do Rio do Peixe Member, Fig. 2). Paula e Silva et al. (2009) 145 

detailed the basal section of the Adamantina Formation, which formed by successive 146 

sandstone bodies with increasing thickness and grain size. Alkaline extrusive bodies, 147 

described as Taiúva Analcimite (Coutinho et al., 1982), occur in the lower Adamantina 148 

Formation. Paula e Silva et al. (2006) interpreted the lower section to be small lacustrine 149 

deltas. The upper portion of the Adamantina Fm. (sensu Paula e Silva et al., 2009), here 150 

defined as Presidente Prudente Member (or Presidente Prudente Fm after Fernandes and 151 

Coimbra, 1996), is represented by meandering to braided fluvial deposits, overlying the basal 152 



deltaic-lacustrine sediments. The upper section of the Bauru basin is represented by the 153 

Marilia Fm., which is characterized by an increase in the aridity of the basin. The Marília Fm. 154 

is composed of alluvial deposits, such as an alluvial plain (ephemeral braided systems) with 155 

small lakes (Carvalho et al., 2004) in the form of marginal fans (Paula e Silva et al. 2009) (Fig. 156 

2).  157 

 158 

 159 

3. Materials and methods 160 

 161 

Twenty-nine sandstone samples were collected from the Caiuá, Santo Anastácio 162 

and Lower (Vale do Rio do Peixe Member) and Upper (Presidente Prudente Member) 163 

Adamantina Formation in the southwestern portion of the Bauru Basin, São Paulo State, 164 

Brazil (Fig. 1). Previous analyses have already been published by Dias et al. (2010) and Dias 165 

et al. (2011), which correspond to 12 samples dated by FTM and 5 samples dated by the U-166 

Pb zircon method. In this work, we carried out an additional 17 analyses using the FT method 167 

and 5 analyses using the U-Pb zircon method. Thus, we integrated the information gathered 168 

from 29 samples dated by FTM, 10 of which were dated by the combined FT and U-Pb dating 169 

methods; thus, the FT apparent ages of 376 grains and U-Pb detrital zircon ages of 158 170 

grains in total were determined. Figure 1 shows a geological map of the study area with the 171 

sample locations, and figure 2 shows the stratigraphy and depositional environment of the 172 

sedimentary units from Bauru Basin, as proposed by Paula e Silva et al. (2009). 173 

 174 

3.1. Materials 175 

Zircons were separated by conventional procedures using heavy liquids and a 176 

magnetic separator after concentrating by hand panning. Zircons were handpicked for FTM 177 



and LA-MC-ICP-MS analyses. First, the zircons were mounted and polished in Teflon for FT 178 

analyses. During the assembly process, the zircons were ground, polished and etched; a 179 

binocular magnifying glass Carl-Zeiss, model Citoval 2, was used to observe the materials. A 180 

polishing machine and sandpapers with grit sizes of 1200, 2400 and 4000 were used to grind 181 

the zircons, which were then polished using a polishing cloth and diamond paste, with 1 and 182 

¼ µm granulometries. Finally, a digitally controlled oven was used to etch the zircons. The 183 

zircon FT ages were obtained at the Departamento de Física, Química e Biologia of UNESP, 184 

Brazil, under a Leica DMRX microscope. For FT analyses, the samples were irradiated in the 185 

nuclear reactor of IPEN/CNEN in São Paulo State, Brazil. After the FT zircon dating was 186 

performed, the U-Pb zircon Teflon mounting was adapted to epoxy mounting for U-Pb dating 187 

at the Isotope Geology Laboratory of Rio Grande University, Brazil, using a laser microprobe 188 

(New Wave UP213) coupled to a MC-ICP-MS (Neptune). 189 

 190 

3.2. Methods 191 

 192 

3.2.1. Fission-track analysis (FT)  193 

The Fission-track Method (FTM) has developed into one of the most useful 194 

techniques that is used throughout the geological community to reconstruct the low-195 

temperature thermal history of rocks over geological time. The FT method is based on the 196 

accumulation of narrow damage trails (i.e., fission tracks) in uranium-rich mineral grains (e.g., 197 

apatite, zircon, titanite) and natural glasses, which form as a result of spontaneous nuclear 198 

fission decay of 238U in nature (Price and Walker 1963; Fleischer et al. 1975; Tagami & 199 

O'Sullivan 2005). Uranium fission creates latent tracks, which disrupt the crystalline structure 200 

of materials as a result of the great charge, mass, and energy released during the fission 201 

process. These tracks have a diameter of about 1 Å, which can be observed by optical 202 



microscopy after etching (Wagner & Van den Haute, 1992; Dias et al., 2009). The total kinetic 203 

energy of a fission fragment pair is about 170 MeV (Fleischer, 2004), corresponding to a 204 

range of ~20 ?m in fluorapatite and ~16 ?m in zircon. By etching, the 5-10 nm wide fission 205 

tracks are enlarged to several micrometers, which can be directly observed by optical 206 

microscopy (Gleadow et al., 1986). During track formation, a fission track becomes 207 

discontinuous at each end of the track trajectory, impeding chemicals from further etching the 208 

material (Villa et al., 1999). This process results in etched lengths of ~16 ?m in apatite (Green 209 

et al., 1986) and ~11 ?m in zircon (Yamada et al., 1995).  210 

The time elapsed since fission tracks began to accumulate is estimated by 211 

determining the density of accumulated tracks in a particular material in relation to the 212 

uranium content of that material. Chemical etching can be used to enlarge fission tracks that 213 

have formed within a mineral to make them readily observable under an ordinary optical 214 

microscope (Price and Walker, 1962). The age is obtained by counting both the fossil (238U 215 

spontaneous fission) and the induced (235U induced fission) tracks using an optical 216 

microscope. The induced tracks are obtained by irradiating a sample with thermal neutrons in 217 

a nuclear reactor, which causes the fission of the 235U isotope. Within the FTM, two methods 218 

are used to carry out dating. In the External Detector Method (EDM), spontaneous fission 219 

tracks are measured in a mineral, and the induced fission tracks are measured using a 220 

detector external to the mineral (mica muscovite, for instance). In the Population Method, 221 

induced and spontaneous fission tracks are measured in the mineral itself (Wagner and Van 222 

der Haute, 1992). In this study, the ages of the zircon fission tracks were determined using a 223 

mathematical equation presented in Iunes et al. (2002, 2005).  224 

Using the FTM, in zircon, both age and thermal events can be determined in 225 

regions of geological interest. Because the closure temperature of zircon is ~ 240 ºC, which 226 

corresponds to temperatures at which the tracks are retained over geological time, it is 227 



possible to determine ages close to the crystallization ages of some minerals (Tagami, 2005). 228 

This method can be also used in oil research because at the depths at which apatite (with a 229 

closure temperature of ~ 120 oC) suffers total annealing zircon can still provide information 230 

about the thermal evolution of the basin where the perforation was made (Yamada et al, 231 

1998, 2003). For these and other reasons, the FTM has developed into one of the most useful 232 

techniques used throughout the geological community, 233 

Zircon has become one of the most important minerals for studying sediment 234 

provenance and the exhumation history of orogenic belts. The usefulness of zircon lies in its 235 

commonness in many igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary rocks, its resistance to 236 

weathering and abrasion, and its ability to be dated using various isotopic methods. With its 237 

relatively high concentrations of uranium and thorium, zircon is one of the most useful 238 

minerals used to unravel the Earth’s history recorded in rocks (Bernet and Garver, 2005; 239 

Tagami, 2005). 240 

The ability of zircon to retain information about the most recent thermal history of a 241 

source area is invaluable in elucidating the geological processes and system responses 242 

experienced by the area over a range of geodynamic settings. As a consequence, the FTM 243 

paired with zircon has been extensively employed, along with other radiometric dating 244 

methods such as U-Pb (for instance, Davis et al. 2003; Chemale et al., 2012; Barredo et al., 245 

2012) and (U-Th)/He techniques (Reiners 2005), to understand the thermochronology of 246 

rocks in a variety of geological settings, i.e., thermal history analysis of basement rocks for 247 

orogenic studies, thermochronology using detrital zircon grains in sedimentary rocks for 248 

provenance analysis and thermal history analysis in or near faults (Carter, 1999; Garver et al. 249 

1999; DeCelles et al., 2000; Hasebe and Tagami, 2001; Spikings et al., 2001; Yamada et al., 250 

2003; Hasebe and Watanabe, 2004; Garver, 2003; Dias et al., 2010 and 2011). 251 

 252 



3.2.1.1. FT annealing phenomena 253 

Knowledge of the stability and annealing of fission tracks is critically important in 254 

decoding the geological history recorded by a host mineral. The thermal annealing of fission 255 

tracks at increased temperature (or time) is a process during which the amorphous, 256 

disordered core is gradually restored to the ordered structure of a crystalline matrix. This 257 

behavior in latent tracks can be directly observed by TEM (Paul and Fitzgerald, 1992; Paul, 258 

1993; Jaskierowicz et al., 2004; Li et al., 2011).  259 

The present understanding of the annealing process is largely limited to 260 

mathematical fits to data for etched track lengths as a function of temperature, time and 261 

composition. The internal structure of latent fission tracks controls the annealing process and, 262 

correspondingly, the shortening of track lengths. However, the empirical equations do not 263 

reflect the relationship between the internal structure of tracks and their annealing behavior 264 

because the structural information of tracks is lost as a result of chemical etching. Even a 265 

highly cited physical model of the process has met considerable criticism in the absence of 266 

actual observations of the atomic-scale process (Carlson, 1990; Crowley, 1993; Green et al., 267 

1993). Atomic-scale studies of fission track fading have long been recognized as necessary 268 

for the development of quantitative models of fission track formation and annealing (Rabone 269 

et al., 2008; Li et al., 2011). 270 

According to Tagami and O'Sullivan (2005), the annealing process is characterized 271 

by the development of irregular morphology at the track-matrix boundary, segmentation of the 272 

track, i.e., appearance of gaps, an increase in the spacing between segments, the shape of 273 

which approaches a sphere, and instantaneous healing of spheres, with an observable 274 

minimum diameter of ~3 nm. The annealing likely occurs through the diffusion of interstitial 275 

atoms and lattice vacancies, which recombine as a result of their thermal activation due to 276 

heating.  277 



In a recent study, Li et al. (2011) performed in situ thermal annealing experiments 278 

of latent tracks that demonstrated that the annealing mechanisms proposed for amorphous 279 

tracks in zircon is a consequence of the recombination of vacancies and interstitials with an 280 

amorphous track in zircon (entirely different from those of the porous tracks in apatite where 281 

shrinkage of the track results from the thermo-emission of vacancies from the porous 282 

channel). The composition of an amorphous track is not significantly different from that of the 283 

surrounding solid. The small chemical difference results in a low surface tension and low 284 

mobility of atoms along the track surface. This structure does not favor track segmentation. 285 

Therefore, defect recombination is the main mechanism through which the amorphous track 286 

decreases in size at elevated temperatures.  287 

If a host rock is subjected to elevated temperatures, fission tracks that have formed 288 

up to that point in time are shortened progressively and eventually erased by the thermal 289 

recovery (i.e., annealing) of the damage. The FTM is based on the knowledge of the kinetics 290 

of this length shortening due to time and temperature. Experimental studies have identified 291 

several factors that may cause annealing, including temperature, time, pressure, chemical 292 

solutions, and ionizing radiation (Fleischer et al., 1965; Ahrens et al., 1970; Gleadow, 1978; 293 

Tagami et al., 1990). Of these factors, temperature is the most important for the minerals 294 

commonly used in geological applications (Gallagher et al., 1998).  295 

The quantitative description of annealing kinetics is provided by annealing models 296 

(Yamada et al., 1995, Galbraith & Laslett, 1997; Tagami et al.,1998; Guedes et al., 2005a; 297 

Murakami et al., 2006; Moreira et al., 2010). Some of these models attempt to establish a 298 

correlation between certain parameters and physical phenomena (Carlson, 1990; Guedes et 299 

al., 2005a, 2005b).  300 

In Gallagher et al. (1998), the authors reported that annealing is a consequence of 301 

a thermally activated diffusion process and that the temperature range over which annealing 302 



occurs varies for different minerals and depends on the heating rate (see Wagner and Van 303 

den Haute, 1992). The closure temperature is associated with the annealing concept. In a 304 

geochronological system, the closure temperature may be defined as the temperature at the 305 

time corresponding to the apparent age. The temperature recorded by a ”frozen“ chemical 306 

system, in which a solid phase in contact with a large reservoir has cooled slowly from high 307 

temperatures, is formally identical to the geochronological closing temperature (for more 308 

details, see Dodson, 1973; Gallagher et al., 1998; Bernet, 2009).  309 

Another important concept is the lag-time. The lag-time of a sample is the time 310 

required for the sample to cool, be exhumed to the surface, and then become deposited in a 311 

nearby basin. As a rock is exhumed to the surface, the rock cools below the closure 312 

temperatures of various thermochronometers. Eventually, the rock reaches the surface, 313 

where it is subject to erosion. Regarding time, the process of erosion and sediment transport 314 

is generally regarded as geologically instantaneous (Heller et al. 1992; Bernet et al. 2004a), 315 

but this is not always the case. The lag-time integrates the time between closure and the time 316 

of deposition and mainly represents the time needed to exhume the rock to the surface 317 

(Bernet and Garver, 2005).  318 

Perhaps the most distinctive aspect of performing FT analysis on zircon that has 319 

not been partially or fully reset after deposition is that the cooling ages recorded in the 320 

sedimentary detritus can be related to past thermal events in the source terrain. In many 321 

cases, these cooling events are directly related to the uplift and exhumation of source rock 322 

such that cooling ages provide a direct link between long-term sediment supply and sediment 323 

accumulation (see figure 3). In this case, lag time is defined as the difference between the 324 

peak age and the depositional age (Garver and Brandon, 1994a; Garver et al., 1999), and it 325 

represents the lag or difference between closure in the source and deposition in the adjacent 326 

basin.  327 



On geological time scales, the latter interval is negligible. In the geological settings 328 

of active volcanism, the lag-time is nearly zero as a result of eruption and deposition in 329 

flanking basins. In non-volcanic cases, rock in the source area is exhumed and passes 330 

through a closure isotherm at a certain depth, at which time the lag-time clock is set. In this 331 

case, the lag time represents the time required for the rock to be exhumed to the surface and 332 

eroded and for the zircon to then be transported to an adjacent basin. Thus, the lag time is a 333 

function of the exhumation rate in a source area (Bernet and Garver, 2005; Hofmann, 2006). 334 

A more detailed description about the consequences of the lag-time is provided in the next 335 

section. 336 

 337 

3.2.1.2. Provenance for detrital zircon fission track data 338 

The density of observable fission tracks in zircon is dependent upon past thermal 339 

history, and the robustness of zircon is reflected by an FT partial annealing zone that occurs 340 

at higher temperatures than those for apatite, ranging between 180 and 320ºC (for 106-108 341 

years), although the upper bound is poorly defined because of a lack of suitable geological 342 

constraint (Tagami et al., 1998) data that record the thermotectonic evolution of a source 343 

terrain. Such information is central to understanding the temporal relationships between a 344 

developing source region and sedimentation in adjacent basins. 345 

The application of detrital zircon data to monitoring sediment source region 346 

evolution, however, is dependent upon geological setting, and several factors should be 347 

considered. Detrital zircon FT ages are therefore related to the time of cooling through this 348 

temperature interval. For volcanic/igneous grains that have not experienced post-formation 349 

track annealing temperatures, the measured FT age will record the original age of formation. 350 

In contrast, zircons derived from a metamorphic terrain will record post-metamorphic 351 



exhumational cooling with apparent ages related to the cooling path through the critical 352 

isotherms that define the zircon PAZ (Carter and Bristow, 2000). 353 

Figure 3 (modified of Carter and Bristow, 2000) shows the potential range of detrital 354 

zircon FT source ages and associated cooling paths. Zircons derived from volcanic eruptions 355 

and tectonic denudation will undergo geologically instantaneous cooling (paths A and B), 356 

whereas zircons derived from interior stable cratons will generally experience more protracted 357 

cooling history paths (paths C and D). Recycled sediments may contain zircons derived from 358 

a variety of cooling paths (paths A, B, C and D).  359 

Large temporal gaps between cooling, erosion and burial introduce uncertainty 360 

regarding the zircon origin (increased potential for sediment recycling), unless corroborated 361 

by independent data. Thus, in this study, double-dating was applied for detrital zircon of the 362 

Bauru sedimentary basin. Regarding the cooling paths (figure 3b), 37% of our grains 363 

presented instantaneous cooling and r mountain exhumation (paths A and B), 22% presented 364 

a protracted cooling history (path C) and 41.3% had a large time gap between zircon cooling 365 

and subsequent erosion, transport, and redeposition (path D). The results and discussion 366 

section will provide more details. 367 

 368 

3.2.1.3. Analytical procedures 369 

The amount of detritus rocks collected in exploration wells was ca. 1 kg, while in 370 

samples collected at the surface, it was over 15 kg. This difference in the amount of available 371 

material indicates the importance of the methodology employed, where grains hybrids (Tello 372 

et al., 2012 in press) and materials that present etching anisotropy are used (Dias et al., 373 

2009). Zircons were separated from rock samples by conventional techniques, such as 374 

crushing, magnetic separation (isodynamic separator), using heavy liquids and handpicking.  375 



The separated zircon grains were then collected with a sharp tip and, with the aid of 376 

a binocular magnifying glass, mounted on an aluminum sheet. The grains were mounted with 377 

their C-axes parallel to each other. The mounted grains formed a 10x10 square, totaling 100 378 

zircon grains in each assembly. The grains were then encrusted in Teflon® PFA. 379 

The assemblies were ground in three stages: polishing manually using 1200 380 

sandpaper (~ 10 ?m); polishing manually using 2400 sandpaper (~ 5 ?m) for 2 minutes; and 381 

polishing using sandpaper 4000 (~ 3 ?m) for 5 minutes on a polishing machine at 60 rpm. 382 

Then, the samples were polished with diamond paste with granulometries of 1 and ¼ ?m for 5 383 

and 10 minutes, respectively, by using a polishing machine at 60 rpm. All of the zircon 384 

samples in this study were etched with a NaOH:KOH (1:1) solution at (225 ± 2) ºC for 18 h.  385 

The samples were then juxtaposed with muscovite micas (External Detector 386 

Method - EDM) and stacked with uranium-doped glasses (CN5) calibrated against uranium 387 

thin films (Iunes et al., 2002). Thermal neutron irradiation was performed in the nuclear 388 

reactor of IPEN/CNEN – São Paulo. The mean neutron fluence obtained via the neutron 389 

dosimeters was (5.98 ± 0.29) x 1014 cm-2.  390 

After counting the fossil (?s) and induced tracks (?i), the samples were dated by 391 

using the absolute neutron dosimetry approach presented in Iunes et al. (2002), through 392 

which the following values were used: C238 = 0.99275 (Lederer and Shirley, 1978), ?F = 8.35 X 393 

10-17 a-1 (Guedes et al., 2003a), ? = 1.55125 X 10-10 a-1 (Lederer and Shirley, 1978), g = 0.684 394 

(Iwano & Danhara, 1998). 395 

 396 

3.2.2. U-Pb in situ dating 397 

All zircon mountings used for FTM determination (ca. 1 cm x 1 cm) were mounted 398 

in a 2.5-cm-diameter circular epoxy mount. Images of the zircons were obtained using an 399 

optical microscope (Leica MZ 125) and a backscatter electron microscope (Jeol JSM 5800).  400 



Zircon grains were dated using a laser ablation microprobe (New Wave UP213) 401 

coupled to a MC-ICP-MS (Neptune) at the Isotope Geology Laboratory of UFRGS. Isotope 402 

data were acquired under the static mode with a spot size of 25 µm for the same zircons 403 

dated by FTM and, in most cases, in the same region of the zircon grains. Laser-induced 404 

elemental fractional and instrumental mass discrimination were corrected using a reference 405 

zircon (GJ-1) (Jackson et al., 2004), following the measurement of two GJ-1 analyses for 406 

every ten samples of zircon spots. For common Pb correction, we assumed that the 204Pb 407 

values, obtained from zircons, share the same Pb composition (Stacey and Kramers, 1975), 408 

assuming concordant ages of 206Pb/238U and 207Pb/206Pb (as estimated age). 409 

The isotope ratios and inter-element fractionation of the data obtained by the MC-410 

ICP-MS instrument were evaluated by interspersing the GJ-1 standard zircon in every set of 411 

zircon samples (spots). The number of analyzed spots varied because it depended on the 412 

zircon homogeneity and the amount of Pb and U. Thus, the GJ-1 standard zircon was used to 413 

estimate the necessary external corrections and corrections for internal instrumental 414 

fractionation. The GJ-1 zircon and sample were assembled in the same mounting. The 415 

operating conditions of the laser (New Wave UP213) and MC-ICP-MS (Neptune) were as 416 

follows: laser output power: 6 J/cm2; shot repetition rate: 10 Hz; laser spot: 25 and 40 µm; cup 417 

configuration: Faradays 206Pb, 208Pb, 232Th, 238U; MIC’s 202Hg, 204Hg+204Pb, 207Pb; gas input: 418 

coolant flow (Ar) 15 l/min, auxiliary flow (Ar) 0.8 l/min, carrier flow 0.75 l/min (Ar) + 0.45 l/min 419 

(He); acquisition: 50 cycles of 1.048 s. 420 

The 204Pb values obtained from the zircons were assumed to share a common Pb 421 

composition, assuming concordant ages of 206Pb/238U and 207Pb/206Pb (as estimated age). In 422 

this case, we estimated the radiogenic composition of 206Pb and Pb207 using the equation for 423 

the fraction of non-radiogenic 206Pb (Williams,1998): f206= [206Pb/204Pb]c/[206 Pb /204Pb]s and 424 



f207= [207Pb/204Pb]c/[207Pb /204Pb]s. Additional details regarding U-Pb in situ dating can be 425 

found in Chemale et al. (2011). 426 

 427 

 428 

4. Results of combined zircon dating 429 

The pioneering work in which FTM and U-Pb analysis were combined to study 430 

detrital zircons was performed by Carter & Moss (1999) and Carter & Bristow (2000). While 431 

each detrital zircon dating technique may provide unique source information, in any study, 432 

there invariably remain outstanding questions that arise regarding the limitations of each 433 

method. By adopting a dual zircon dating approach, combining both FTM and U-Pb analysis 434 

to study the same samples and/or grains, it is possible to overcome such limitations and 435 

extract the optimum amount of provenance information that is related to both the age 436 

structure and thermal evolution of the immediate source terrains.  437 

An improvement in the methodology described in Carter & Moss (1999) was carried 438 

out and reported in Dias et al. (2010 and 2011). The ages found by both methods (detailed in 439 

the table 2) were obtained in the same grains and, more specifically, in the same areas of the 440 

grains (Figures 4 and 5). The grains were first dated by FTM and then by the U-Pb method. 441 

 442 

4.1. FTM results 443 

The results of the FTM analysis are shown in table S1, and figures 6 and 7 show 444 

the fission track age distribution for 29 samples of Bauru Basin, which are divided into the 445 

Cauiá Fm. (Depositional Sequence 1), Santo Anastácio Fm. (Depositional Sequence 2) and 446 

Lower and Upper Adamantina Fm. (Depositional Sequence 3). Electron backscattering 447 

images of the dated zircon grains are shown in figures 4 and 5, including the apparent FT and 448 

U-Pb zircon age for the same grain. On the basis of all the FTM ages, including the three 449 



depositional sequences, it was possible to distinguish the main age populations: 159 ± 8 Ma 450 

(3%), 277 ± 6 Ma (26%), 390 ± 9 Ma (35%), 526 ± 29 Ma (24%), 654 ± 30 Ma (11%) and 780 451 

± 190 Ma (0.01%). This last population was estimated, whereas the five first were calculated 452 

using an unmixed zircon histogram (Ludwig, 2003). 453 

Individual histograms with normalized age probability (apparent zircon fission track 454 

ages) are shown for each sample analyzed (Fig. 6). 455 

Two samples of the Caiuá Fm. (Depositional Sequence 1) were dated, ZPS21 and 456 

ZMDC20. They presented three main age populations: 323 ± 24 Ma, 467 ± 54 Ma and 540 ± 457 

100 Ma. Only one zircon grain presented an age of 721 ± 155 Ma (sample ZMDC20). 458 

Two samples of the Santo Anastácio Fm. (Depositional Sequence 2), ZPEB37 and 459 

ZMP16, revealed three main populations: 130 ± 38 Ma, 306 ± 27 Ma and 538 ± 24 Ma. The 460 

oldest age was 776 ± 159 Ma (sample ZPEB37), and the youngest was 121 ± 34 Ma 461 

(ZMP15). 462 

In the Vale do Rio do Peixe Member (Lower Adamantina Fm, Depositional 463 

Sequence 3), 8 samples were dated (ZPP4, ZBV33, ZAMB6, ZMAB26, ZRF43, ZMA25 and 464 

ZBC34). Three main age populations were determined: 288 ± 49 Ma, 420 ± 55 Ma ad 573 ± 465 

34 Ma. The oldest age was 825 ± 200 Ma (sample ZRF43), and the youngest was 152 ± 41 466 

Ma. (samples ZRF43 and ZMAB26). 467 

In the Presidente Prudente Member (Upper Adamantino Fm., Depostional 468 

Sequence 3), 7 samples were dated (ZPV22, ZFMB, ZTA2, ZAL13, ZTA3, ZSE12 and ZNP9). 469 

The three main age groups identified in this member were 206 ± 16 Ma, 363 ± 17 Ma and 650 470 

± 38 Ma, with oldest and youngest ages being 865 ± 221 Ma (ZMA25- G01) and 93 ± 34 Ma 471 

(ZRF43-G03), respectively. 472 

 473 

4.2. U-Pb zircon dating 474 



The U-Pb ages obtained from zircon grains are interpreted to be magmatic because 475 

the grains’ Th/U ratios vary from 0.20 to 1.72 (with exception of grain 4[B2], sample ZPE36). 476 

The Th/U ratio > 0.2 is interpreted to be the limit for igneous versus metamorphic zircons, 477 

which usually have very low values (10-2 to 10-3) (e.g., Cates & Mojzsis, 2009). 478 

The Caiuá Fm. (Depositional Sequence 1) presents three main age groups, 579 ± 3 479 

Ma, 1144 ± 15 Ma and 2032 ± 13 Ma, and a subordinated group, 1589 ± 29 Ma. The Santo 480 

Anastácio Fm. (Depositional Sequence 2) presents three main age groups, 638 ± 5 Ma, 1716 481 

± 27 Ma and 2775 ± 23 Ma, and a subordinate group, 1036 ± 13 Ma. As in the case of the 482 

Vale do Rio do Peixe member (Lower Adamantina Fm - Depositional Sequence 3), three 483 

main age groups were identified: 658 ± 3 Ma, 1635 ± 9 Ma ad 2003 ± 8 Ma, with 484 

subordination in the Neoproterozoic (1008 ± 7 Ma). In the Presidente Prudente member 485 

(Upper Adamantina Fm - Depositional Sequence 3), four age groups were recognized: 579 ± 486 

5 Ma, 1020 ± 10 Ma, 1953 ± 15 Ma and 2819 ± 25 Ma. In this member, one detrital zircon 487 

grain age of 90 ± 22 Ma was observed (see S2). 488 

 489 

5. Discussion 490 

 491 

5.1. Apparent FT zircon ages  492 

The obtained FT zircon ages (Table S1 and S2; and figs. 6, 7 and 9b) of the Bauru 493 

Basin reveal a much more complex history when compared to modern orogenic belts. The 494 

apparent zircon ages of the collected samples is herein evaluated after the three depositional 495 

cycles of the Bauru Basin and are shown in Figures 6 and 7. Analyzed samples of 496 

Depositional Sequence 1 belong to the fluvial meandering system of the Caiuá Fm. The 497 

obtained zircon ages were clearly affected by the zircons, which passed the total annealing to 498 

partial retention zone between 420 and 360 Ma and between 250 and 200 Ma; these results 499 



could be related to the large tectonic events of the Famatinian and Gondwanides orogeny 500 

along the western margin of the South American Platform. The samples of the overlying 501 

Depositional Sequence 2, which belong to the Santo Anastácio Fm., contain apparent ages 502 

that are chronocorrelated with the Brasiliano, Famatianian and Gondwanides, but there are 503 

also some zircons that were denudated during the Tonian orogeny of the Brazilian Shield. 504 

Paula e Silva et al., (2009) report that the main river flow of the basal units was from SW to 505 

NE, while the overlying Santa Anastácio presented a paleocurrent running northward, 506 

southeast-eastward and probably westward. The zircons with apparent ages of about 750-507 

850 Ma may have come from the west from the Bauru Basin,probable from the Goiás 508 

Magmatic Arc rocks. 509 

During Depositional Sequence 3, a larger expansion of the Bauru Basin occurred. 510 

Samples from the Vale do Rio do Peixe Member showed apparent zircon age populations of 511 

220-320 Ma, 350-450 Ma and 500-600 Ma. This time span was also the period of large 512 

crustal formation at the border and central part of South America, corresponding to the 513 

Gondwanides, Famatinian and Brasiliano orogenic time. The overlying lithologies from the 514 

Presidente Prudente Member (upper Adamantina Fm.) show behavior similar to those of the 515 

Vale do Rio do Peixe Member. 516 

Individual apparent ages between 120 and 150 Ma were determined in the four 517 

stratigraphic units and interpreted to belong to the zircon formed during the Early Cretaceous 518 

Paraná magmatism (as path A in figure 3). 519 

 520 

5.2. U-Pb zircon ages 521 

In the histograms of individualized stratigraphic units, the Caiuá, Santo Anastácio 522 

Fm. and Vale Rio do Peixe and Presidente Prudente Mb. (Fig. 8), a strong component of the 523 

Brasiliano source (between 600 and 500) is recognized. The Early Brasiliano (Tonian ages), 524 



Mesoproterozoic (Stenian ages) and Paleoproterozoic (Statherian and Rhyacian ages) occur 525 

as subordinate zircon age populations. Archean peaks are exhibited by a few zircons from the 526 

Santa Anastácio Fm. and Presidente Prudente Mb. Some Ordovician zircons were dated in 527 

the Caiuá Fm. and Adamantina Fm., which can correspond to the magmatism of the latest 528 

stage of the Brasiliano Cycle or were transported from the Famatinian Terrain situated to the 529 

west, in the Pre-Cordillera and main Andean region (e.g.: Ramos, 1988, Pankhurst et al., 530 

1998). The Mesozoic zircon in the Presidente Prudente Mb. 90 ± 22 Ma (ZPP14-G4) is the 531 

youngest detrital zircon from the 158 dated grains in the studied samples; here, it is 532 

interpreted as the maximum depositional age for the Upper Section of the Bauru Basin. 533 

 534 

5.3. Tracking the main tectonic events of South American Platform based on the 535 

Upper Mesozoic Intracratonic Basin 536 

Through the analyses of the detrital zircon of the intracratonic Bauru Basin, formed 537 

between 90 and 73 Ma, it was possible to recognize the main tectonic events that took place 538 

in the South American Platform. The U-Pb zircon detrital ages provided information on the 539 

main source areas for the sedimentary rocks of the Bauru Basin, which can be grouped into 540 

the main Brasiliano Cycle (650-500 Ma), early Brasiliano (850 to 700 Ma), Sunsas-Grenvile 541 

Cycle (1000-1200), Statherian Cycle (1700-1800 Ma) , Rhyacian (2000-2200 Ma) and Jequié 542 

Cycle (Figs. 8 and 9). The sedimentary structures and isopach of the Caiuá and Pirapozinho 543 

Fm. point to main sedimentary transport from SW to NE, while the overlying sequences, the 544 

Santo Anastácio, Adamantina and Marilia Fm., present a more complex sedimentary infill, 545 

with sedimentary supply from the SW, W and E (Paula e Silva et al., 2009). In this case, the 546 

potential areas for the supply of sediments for the Depositional Sequence 1 would be mainly 547 

those areas situated to the SW of the Bauru Basin (the Pampean-Brasiliano terrains) and to 548 

the W (Goiás Magmatic Arch). The sediment source of the overlying units, Depositional 549 



Sequence 2 and 3, were transported from the SW (the Pampean-Brasiliano terrains) and to 550 

the W (Goiás Magmatic Arch), as well as probably from the E (Ribeira Belt). 551 

In the diagram of U-Pb age versus FT age (Figure 9a) on detrital zircons of the 552 

Bauru Basin, it is possible to distinguish four major epochs of denudation: 553 

1) The first shows an apparent age concentrated between 850 and 700 Ma, 554 

which corresponds to the time of the main oceanic arc collision of the Goiás 555 

Magmatic Arc (Pimentel & Fuck, 1992, Pimentel et al., 2000b). The zircons 556 

formed during the Rhyacian (Transmazonian Cycle), Statherian, Stenian 557 

(Sunsas-Grenvile) and Tonian (time of the Goiás Island Arc collision).  558 

2) The second group of apparent zircon age comprises those zircon samples 559 

with TF ages ranging from 490 Ma to 650 Ma. There are five major 560 

concentrations of U-Pb absolute age: the Rhyacian (Transamazonian), 561 

Stahetrian, Stenian (Sunsas-Grenvile Cycle), Tonian (early Brasiliano) and 562 

Brasiliano. The last concentration is the direct record of the exhumation 563 

process of the Brasiliano Orogeny. 564 

3) The third group of sample consists of FT ages ranging from 480 to 360 Ma, 565 

with the U-Pb age of the Rhyacian, Stenian, Tonian and dominant Brasiliano 566 

ones (650-500 Ma). Although these zircons came from Brasiliano and 567 

Paleoproterozoic rocks, many of these zircons passed the total annealing to 568 

partial retention zone during the period of the Famatinian Orogenic process 569 

along the western margin of the South American Platform, which is 570 

estimated to have occurred between 510 and 360 Ma (Pankhurst et al., 571 

1998; Loewy et al., 2004; Ramos, 1998; Bahlburg et. al., 2009 and 572 

references therein). 573 



4) The last group is represented by those zircons with FT apparent ages 574 

between 350 and 220 Ma, which correspond to the span of the 575 

Gondwanides Cycle active along the western margin of the South American 576 

Platform and Pangaea formation. The U-Pb ages of the same zircons 577 

indicate a sedimentary component of the following crustal accretion: 578 

Rhyacian (Transmazonian Cycle) Steneian (Sunsas-Grenvile Cycle), Tonian 579 

(Early Brasiliano Cycle ) and dominant Brasiliano cycle (650 to 500 Ma)  580 

The Mesozoic extensional events of the South American Platform can be recorded 581 

by those FT zircon ages between 120 and 150 Ma and U-Pb zircon at 90 ± 22 Ma (Figs. 6 582 

and 7). 583 

The main crustal accretion of the Brazilian Shield, the crystalline basement of the 584 

Bauru Basin and surrounding areas were very well tracked by the U-Pb zircon ages obtained 585 

from samples of Depositional Sequences 1, 2 and 3. The following sedimentary sources were 586 

recognized: Transamazonain or Rhyacian rocks (2.2-1.9 Ga) (e.g., Almeida et al., 2000; 587 

Santos et al., 2003), the Staherian extensional event (1.8 to 1.68 Ga) (Chemale et al., 2012), 588 

the Sunsá-Greenvile (1.2-10 Ga) (e.g., Fuck et al., 2008; Santos et al., 2008), Tonian or Early 589 

Brasiliano (0.9-0.7 Ga) ( Pimentel & Fuck, 1992; Pimentel et al., 2000b) and Brasiliano Cycle 590 

(650-500 Ma) (e.g., Almeida et al., 2000; Cordani et al., 2003 and references therein). Some 591 

local Archean zircons dated to the time of the Jequié Cycle were also found. 592 

The FTM zircon ages provided very important information on these recycled zircon 593 

grains or denudation processes, which span from the total annealing zone to the partial 594 

annealing, because we can track the main orogenetic deformation at the border of the South 595 

America Platform during the Famatian and Gondwanides Cycles and the Brasiliano Cycle 596 

(Fig. 9b). The overlap of the FT apparent ages and U-Pb zircon ages corresponds mostly to 597 

the rapid uplift with erosion and the removal of thrusted slices (or exhumation process) of the 598 



Brasilaino Belts (Fig. 9b), as described for the modern orogenic belts (e.g., Bernett et al., 599 

2009). Figure 10 shows the extension of the magmatic arc generated during these orogenic 600 

cycles.  601 

The Famatinian Orogenic Cycle evolved from 510 to 360 Ma (Pankhurst et al., 602 

1998; Loewy et al., 2004; Ramos, 1998; Bahlburg et al., 2009 and references therein). The 603 

Gondwanides along the margin western of the South American Platform formed between 345 604 

and 245 Ma, with a subduction process having started at 345 Ma (Bahlburg et al., 2009) and 605 

a subduction-related process followed by extensive crustal magmatism (collapse-related 606 

magmatism) of the Choyoi type (Kay et al., 1989). The Choiyoi and related magmatic rocks 607 

extend 2500 km from northern Chile to North Patagonia in Argentina, formed between 300 608 

and 245 Ma (Rocha Campos et al., 2011; Fannig et al., in press). This orogenic cycle is very 609 

well constrained to the Chilenia Terrain, Central Andes (Figure 10), which corresponds to the 610 

South American margin against the Cuyania in the Upper Devonian (Ramos, 2000) or 611 

Carboniferous (Bahlburg et al., 2009). 612 

 613 

 614 

6. Conclusions 615 

 616 

The use of double thermochronometer methods, namely, high-temperature U-Pb 617 

and low-temperature FT methods, in the same detrital zircon grains from sedimentary rocks of 618 

the intracratonic Bauru Basin formed between 73 Ma and 90 Ma ago and located in the 619 

interior of the South America Platform, is undeniably a powerful tool that can be used to 620 

unravel the main provenance sources for the basin and the main crustal accretion processes 621 

(orogenic and extensional ones) that occurred in the South America Platform between the 622 

Archean and the Upper Mesozoic. 623 



Samples were collected from the three depositional sequences of the basin that 624 

were deposited in the dominant fluvial and lacustrine environment under arid to semi-arid 625 

conditions, and it was possible, through the in situ U-Pb analyses of detrital zircons, to 626 

distinguish the major accretional events that took place during the Precambrian in the South 627 

American Platform, namely, Archean (Jequié Cycle, 3.0 to 2.7 Ga), Rhyacian (Transmazonian 628 

Cycle, 2.2-1.90 Ga), Statherian (1.80-1.68 Ga), Sunsás (1.2-0.90 Ga), Tonian (Early 629 

Brasiliano, 0.9-075 Ga) and Upper Neoproterozoic (Brasiliano , 0.65-0.50 Ga). 630 

The FT apparent zircon ages of the same zircons complemented the provenance of 631 

the sedimentary units of the Bauru Basin as well as the additional crustal accretion in the 632 

South America Platform from the Neoproterozoic to Mesozoic. The FT zircon ages of the 633 

Tonian and Cryogenian-Ediacaran, most of which show U-Pb zircon ages close to those 634 

determined by the FTM, suggest that these zircons passed the total annealing zone to the 635 

partial retention zone during the exhumation process of the Early and Main Brasiliano 636 

Orogenic Cycle. However, two major concentrations of ages between 500 and 360 Ma and 637 

between 345 and 230 Ma are also recognized, which may track the two main Paleozoic 638 

Orogenic Cycles along the western border of the South American Platform and the 639 

Famatinian and Gondwanides Cycles in the Upper Cretaceous Bauru Basin. Thus, the 640 

integration of sedimentary flow, as determined by the paleocurrent and isopach information, 641 

during the deposition of the Bauru Basin with the potential source areas and the combination 642 

of U-Pb and FT zircon dating enabled us to distinguish the main source areas as well as the 643 

main tectonic events in the South America Platform. 644 

The most significant contribution of this study was the ability to address the different 645 

paths of sample cooling through the zircon FT partial annealing zone, paths A, B, C and 646 

D.(Fig. 3), and estimate the proportion of zircons that cooled during rapid uplift (exhumation) 647 

or magma cooling versus those grains that presented steady, long-term cooling associated 648 



with slow exhumation or that spent a long time in the partial retention zone and passed to 649 

zone of stability as a result of rapid exhumation. The difficulty associated with this study is 650 

attributed to the fact that an intracratonic basin has a polyhistoric memory and has a variety of 651 

zircons with a single or even multiple cooling histories (PAZ). 652

Effects of Etching on Zircon Grains and Its Implications for the
Fission Track Method

CARLOS ALBERTO TELLO SA?ENZ,* EDUARDO AUGUSTO CAMPOS CURVO,
AIRTON NATANAEL COELHO DIAS, CLEBER JOSE? SOARES,
CARLOS JOSE? LEOPOLDO CONSTANTINO, IGOR ALENCAR, SANDRO GUEDES,
ROSANE PALISSARI, and JULIO CESAR HADLER NETO
Departamento de F??sica Qu??mica e Biologia, UNESP Universidade Estadual Paulista, 19060-900 Presidente Prudente, SP, Brazil (C.A.T.S.,

E.A.C.C., A.N.C.D., C.J.L.C.); Instituto de Geocie?ncias e Cie?ncias Exatas, UNESP Universidade Estadual Paulista, 13506-900, Rio Claro, SP,
Brazil (C.J.S.); and Instituto de F??sica ‘‘Gleb Wataghin’’, Universidade Estadual de Campinas, UNICAMP, 13083-970 Campinas, SP, Brazil

(I.A., S.G., R.P., J.C.H.N.)

Studies of zircon grains using optical microscopy, micro-Raman

spectroscopy, and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) have been carried

out to characterize the surface of natural zircon as a function of etching

time. According to the surface characteristics observed using an optical

microscope after etching, the zircon grains were classified as: (i)

homogeneous; (ii) anomalous, and (iii) hybrid. Micro-Raman results

showed that, as etching time increases, the crystal lattice is slightly altered

for homogeneous grains, it is completely damaged for anomalous grains,

and it is altered in some areas for hybrid grains. The SEM (energy

dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, EDS) results indicated that, independent of

the grain types, where the crystallinity remains after etching, the chemical

composition of zircon is approximately 33% SiO2:65% ZrO2 (standard

natural zircon), and for areas where the grain does not have a crystalline

structure, there are variations of ZrO2 and, mainly, SiO2. In addition, it is

possible to observe a uniform surface density of fission tracks in grain

areas where the determined crystal lattice and chemical composition are

those of zircon. Regarding hybrid grains, we discuss whether the areas

slightly altered by the chemical etching can be analyzed by the fission

track method (FTM) or not. Results of zircon fission track and U-Pb

dating show that hybrid and homogeneous grains can be used for dating,

and not only homogeneous grains. More than 50 sedimentary samples

from the Bauru Basin (southeast Brazil) were analyzed and show that only

a small amount of grains are homogeneous (10%), questioning the validity

of the rest of the grains for thermo-chronological evolution studies using

zircon FTM dating.

Index Headings: Zircon; Micro-Raman spectroscopy; Fission track

method; Scanning electron microscopy; SEM; Energy dispersive X-ray

spectroscopy; EDS; Zircon crystal lattice; Zircon chemical etching.

INTRODUCTION

The fission track method, FTM, is commonly used to
evaluate thermo-chronological evolution in regions of geolog-
ical interest. This application is based on the accumulation of
fission tracks, originating from spontaneous fission decay of
238U on the geological time scale, and the possibility that these
tracks can be revealed when a mineral is submitted to
appropriate etching. Some minerals to which FTM is
commonly applied include, for instance, apatite and zircon,
whose principal difference is the range of temperatures in
which fission tracks have their lengths partially shortened
(partial annealing zone, PAZ). Thus, from the measurement of
fission track lengths it is possible to infer the interval of time

over which the mineral experienced PAZ temperatures and
then reconstruct its geological thermal history. In the case of
apatite, the PAZ spans between 60 and 110 8C (considering the
time period of 1 Ma, where Ma is ‘‘million years’’). The same
interval is required for maturation of hydrocarbons in Ma (see
Gallagher et al.1 and references therein). For zircon, the PAZ
spans between 190 and 380 8C (for heating durations of 1
Ma).2 In this way, zircon enables the study of more intense
thermal events and/or to find the crystallization age. An
important example of its application is the geological fault
dated by Murakami et al.3 Thus, zircon fission track analysis
complements the information given by the apatite fission track
analysis.

Depending on the sample, laboratory treatments of zircon
may be very laborious, reflecting the scarce annealing data
previously presented.4–6 However, it is possible to use this data
for annealing modeling (e.g., Guedes et al.7). One of the major
issues in the application of FTM to zircon is the track etching.8

Etching and annealing (track fading by temperature9) of fission
tracks in zircon are affected by: (i) crystallization through
magmatic or metamorphic zonation; (ii) metamictization
(partial or total damage of the crystal lattice caused by nuclide
recoil during alpha decay) when the mineral has high
concentration of uranium (U) and thorium (Th) (above 5000
ppm of UO2 þ ThO2),10,11 and (iii) the incorporation of other
minerals. Such events can take place in zircons of igneous or
detrital rocks. In general, at least one of these phenomena can
be identified in natural zircons.

Over the last decade, micro-Raman spectroscopy has been
applied to zircon to analyze radiation effects in the annealing
process. Micro-Raman spectroscopy data present systematic
changes in frequency, relative intensity, and/or band width
according to the dose. These data are related to metamictiza-
tion,11–15 i.e., the loss of the periodic crystal structure. This
phenomenon is the result of the accumulation of radiation
damage over time in the geological timescale.16 In natural
zircons, metamictization is the result of the radioactive decay of
U and Th incorporated during crystal growth (as well as the
decay of their daughter products) and, therefore, the crystalli-
zation degree in a zircon sample may be described by the
relative amounts of the amorphous and swelled crystalline
fractions. According to Wasilewski et al.17 and other research-
ers,18–20 the a-recoil nuclei directly amorphize the structure,
whereas point defects created by particles, together with the
tangent stress from adjacent amorphous regions, induce swelling
of the crystal structure. Palenik et al.11 presented a micro-
analytic study (optical microscopy, Raman spectroscopy, and

high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM)) of
a zircon from Sri Lanka (alluvial zircon, with an estimated age of
570 6 20 Ma), in which they observed zoning resulting from
radiation damage (see also Chakoumakos et al.21). Evidence for
the increased reactivity of metamict zircon is also given by the
discordant ages determined from metamict areas of natural
zircon samples.22–24 However, little attention has been paid to
the role of metamictization on the chemical stability of zircon at
the Earth’s surface.25 Also, little is known about the effect of
chemical etching over the zircon crystal lattice.

In the present work, the study of natural zircon surfaces was
carried out using micro-Raman spectroscopy as a function of
etching time. For this goal, we used a sample, denoted JP,
collected in the Barreiras Formation, near the city of Matacara,
State of Para??ba, northeast Brazil. The Barreiras Formation is a
continental sedimentary deposit along the Brazilian coastline
spanning from the State of Rio de Janeiro to the State of
Amapa?.26 These detrital zircons present a mean uranium
content of 130 ppm (calculated via neutron irradiation against
standard uranium doped glasses) and mean Th/U ratio of 0.7
(calculated from inductively coupled plasma mass spectrom-
etry (ICP-MS) measurements). The scanning electronic
microscopy, SEM (energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS)),
was also used to characterize the zircon surface and to estimate
the concentration of its main chemical oxide elements (ZrO2
and SiO2). Three types of zircon grains were identified after
etching according to their response. They were classified here
as homogeneous, anomalous, and hybrid grains. The aim of
this work is to check the possibility of using hybrid grains in
FTM. As a result, eight grains (homogeneous and hybrid) were
dated by FTM and U-Pb dating to show that these zircon grains
can be indeed used in thermo-geochronology. This work is
complementary to the one carried out for heterogeneous grains,
which show non-uniform fission-track distribution.27

EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES

The characterization of zircon grains was carried out before
and after etching in terms of their surface morphology (optical
microscopy) and crystalline structure (micro-Raman spectros-
copy). Determination of the main chemical oxide elements
(SEM/EDS) was carried out only after the etching. Optical
microscopy and micro-Raman spectroscopy analyses were
done for samples with no etching or with 6, 12, and 18 hours of
etching. The experimental procedure for standard etching is
described by Tagami et al.5 Etching took place in steps until
surface tracks perpendicular to the crystallography C-axis reach
approximately 2 lm width.4 The ideal etching time for samples
used in this work was 18 hours. The SEM (EDS) analyses were
carried out only for 18 hours of etching. The optical
microscopy images were recorded using a microscope Leica
DMRX, with nominal magnification up to 15003, digital
camera (ExwaveHAD Sony, model SSC-DC54A), and Image-
Pro Plus 4.0 program for image acquisition. After etching, it
shows that (i) a typical homogeneous grain surface has its
crystallinity slightly changed after the chemical etching and
presents a uniform fission-track distribution; (ii) an anomalous
grain surface loses the crystallinity presented before etching,
being heavily etching damaged. This etching damage may be
occurring due to several physicochemical phenomena, and not
only due to metamictization. Another possibility is the
incorporation of other minerals;28 and (iii) a hybrid grain
surface presents preserved areas (with crystallinity and fission

tracks, as in the homogeneous grain case) and damaged areas
(as in the anomalous grain case). The zircon classification used
in this work tries to describe an etched surface characteristic,
which may be well known in the fission track community but
has not yet been reported. We could call the hybrid grain (for
instance) a ‘‘patchily over-etched’’ grain, but this classification
implies that one area reveals tracks and another does not.
However, this is typical of grains that present etching
anisotropy, which is not the case here. The hybrid grain
maintains (after etching) areas with tracks while other areas are
completely damaged by the etching.

Micro-Raman spectroscopy was carried out using a
spectrograph micro-Raman Renishaw model in-Via equipped
with a charge-coupled device (CCD) detector, Leica Micro-
scope, lasers at 514.5, 633, and 785 nm, an automatic sample
holder base (which allows X, Y, and Z translations with steps
of 0.1 lm), and gratings with 1800 and 1200 grooves/mm. The
Raman spectra were collected with spatial resolution around 1
lm2, spectral resolution of approximately 2.5 cm?1, and
directly from the grains without any further treatment beyond
the one necessary for the fission track analysis (i.e., polishing
and etching). The measurements were done with the 514.5 nm
laser line focused perpendicular to the C-axis using the 503
objective lens and gratings with 1200 grooves/mm. The SEM
(EDS) measurements29 were performed with a scanning
electron microscope LEO430. The electron beam operated
with energy of 20 keV, working distance of 19 mm, beam
current of 3 3 10?9 A, and vacuum of 1 3 10?5 torr. Samples
were coated with carbon before measurement to avoid charge
effects. The process to obtain grains of zircon utilized
conventional techniques, i.e., by crushing, grinding, magnetic,
and heavy liquid separations. After these, zircon grains were
mounted in a sheet of Teflon PFA and polished. Before
etching, all grains were observed by optical microscopy and
presented a flat surface from characteristic zircon grains. The
etching was done with an eutectic mixture of KOH : NaOH at
(225 6 2)8 C.8,30

RESULTS

Micro-Raman Spectroscopy. Figures 1, 2, and 3 present
the Raman spectra for homogeneous, anomalous, and hybrid
grains, respectively, whose optical images are given in figure
insets. The assignments of the main Raman bands are given in
Table I, which summarizes literature data.31,32 The vibrational
modes are related to Si–O bonding. Raman data (wavenumber,
intensity, relative intensity, and full width at half-maximum
(FWHM)) are shown in Table II.

Homogeneous Grain. The inset in Fig. 1 shows an optical
image obtained with 5003 nominal magnification and reveals a
uniform density of fission tracks for a grain surface after 18
hours of etching. Four Raman spectra were collected over
sequential etching times (without etching and with 6, 12, and
18 hours of etching, see Fig. 1). It can be seen that the absolute
and relative intensity of the peaks decreases as etching time

increases (Table II), but even after 18 hours of etching a
significant percentage of the crystalline structure is maintained.
The latter indicates that this type of grain is suitable for zircon
FTM dating. The same analyses were done for other
homogeneous grain areas and the results are similar. Similar
results were also found for heterogeneous grains.27 However,
